section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to engage children with music, and introduce vocabulary (busy, nibbled).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, How do animals make homes in trees?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Join in singing, rhyming, and word play.
Use sentences with multiple phrases.
Focus attention (self-regulation).
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Describe the life cycles of different plants and animals.
Investigate, describe, and talk about materials from the earth and how they are used.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Challenge children to identify the life stages of different organisms and place them in order.
Guide children to understand that all living organisms go through a life cycle.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What is it like where animals live?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What animal homes do you see in the book? What is each home called?
What animal home can you pretend to make? What is it made of?
Sort different objects from biggest to smallest.
What animal home could you draw? What does it look like?
What materials do you need to make a nest for a bird?
What letter makes the sound at the beginning of the word home? Can you write the letter?
Can you build an animal home with blocks? What animal home will you build?

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder show curiosity and introduce vocabulary (searching, focus).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to The Busy Tree.
Read closely to talk about and practice the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Engage in conversation with a variety of partners, taking turns listening and speaking; Use verbal and nonverbal conversation and group discussion rules.
Understand and use a growing number of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions; Understand and use a growing number of common phrases.
Focus attention (self-regulation).
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Describe the life cycles of different plants and animals.
Investigate, describe, and talk about materials from the earth and how they are used.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function, Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Let children examine different objects under magnifying glasses and talk about what they see.
Challenge children to describe how things look different through the magnifying glass.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What is it like where animals live?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What animals can you find in your book?
Can you act like an animal that lives in a tree?
Draw three trees—one very big tree, smaller tree, and a tiny tree.
What would you change about The Busy Tree?
Find materials to build an animal home.
What letter do you see at the beginning of the word focus? What sound does that letter make?
How can you make your animal home bigger for a bigger animal?

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Language: Listening; Conversation; Sentence Structure; Vocabulary

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share comprehension skill Multiple Meaning, sing a song about animal homes, and introduce the vocabulary (bark, sway).
Start Story Time by revisiting The Busy Tree and asking the guiding question, What makes a tree a good place for animals?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Respond appropriately to spoken language; Follow oral directions.
Join in singing, rhyming, and word play; Use verbal and nonverbal conversation and group discussion rules.
Use sentences with multiple phrases.
Understand multiple meaning words; Respond to instructional language; Understand and use a growing number of question words and prepositions.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more; Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the relationship between plants and animals and their environments.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children build sentences by adding phrases that tell where animals are in relation to their surroundings.
Guide children to understand and use prepositions.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What is it like where animals live?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find different animals’ homes in your book?
Can you pretend to be an animal parent taking care of your babies?
Use blocks to build a home for Scout. How many blocks will you use?
How would you draw a bird’s nest? What color would it be?
How would you draw your favorite animal home?
What letter makes the sound at the beginning of the words tree and trunk?
Pretend you are building a big tree. How tall will your tree be?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. The Busy Tree by Jennifer Ward, illustrated by Lisa Falkenstern. Text copyright © 2009 by Jennifer Ward. Illustrations copyright © 2009 by Lisa Falkenstern. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Two Lions, an imprint of Amazon Children’s Publishing.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: At the Pond

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about what children have learned about animal homes and introduce vocabulary (worms, grasshoppers).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts At the Pond and The Busy Tree.
Read interactively to connect to this week’s Concept Question: What is it like where animals live?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Follow oral directions.
Use sentences with more than one phrase.
Understand multiple meaning words; Respond to instructional language.
Focus attention (self-regulation).
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more; Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Describe life cycles of different plants and animals.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Guide children to understand that the same word can have different meanings.
Challenge children to act out two different meanings of the same word.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What is it like where animals live?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How are the animal homes in this book and At the Pond the same? And how are they different?
Act like a bird who lives in a tree and then act like a bird who lives near a pond. How are they different? How are they the same?
Put different objects in order from biggest to smallest. Which one is the biggest?
Draw an animal that lives in a tree.
Use crayons or markers to color the animal you drew.
What letter makes the first sound in the word pond? Can you point to the letter?
Build a home for an animal. What materials will you use?

Illustrations copyright © 2009 by Lisa Falkenstern. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Two Lions, an imprint of Amazon Children’s Publishing.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Executive Function; Motivation and Creativity

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to have children introduce the vocabulary (roots, march).
Start Story Time by revisiting the book and asking, If you could live in any animal home, which would you choose?
Read and retell interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Show understanding of spoken language.
Tell or retell stories.
Select books and other texts for prereading.
Focus attention (self-regulation).
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the relationship between plants and animals and their environments.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: “What part of a tree would you live in? Why?”
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: What is it like where animals live?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How did the animals in this book make their homes? How would you describe their homes?
Pretend you are squirrel nibbling on an acorn.
Can you describe how a caterpillar grows into a butterfly?
How would you draw the best animal home for your favorite animal?
How would you create your favorite animal’s home?
What letters are there two of in the word root? Can you write that letter?
What materials would you use to build an animal home? Why would you use that material?

Illustrations copyright © 2009 by Lisa Falkenstern. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Two Lions, an imprint of Amazon Children’s Publishing.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Investigate and demonstrate growing understanding of the sounds and intonation of language.
Use sentences with more than one phrase.
Sustain attention to personally chosen or routine (teacher-directed) tasks until completed.
Remain focused on engaging group activities for up to 20 minutes at a time.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Describe life cycles of organisms.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss earth materials and their properties and uses.
Engage in conversations in appropriate ways.
Demonstrate knowledge of verbal conversational rules.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Sustain attention to personally chosen or routine (teacher-directed) tasks until completed.
Remain focused on engaging group activities for up to 20 minutes at a time.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Describe life cycles of organisms.
Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Show understanding by following two-step oral directions.
Investigate and demonstrate growing understanding of the sounds and intonation of language.
Demonstrate knowledge of verbal conversational rules.
Use sentences with more than one phrase.
Demonstrate understanding of instructional language of the classroom.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the relationship of organisms to their environments.
Show understanding by following two-step oral directions and usually follow three step directions.
Use sentences with more than one phrase.
Demonstrate understanding of terms used in the instructional language of the classroom
Sustain attention to personally chosen or routine (teacher-directed) tasks until completed.
Remain focused on engaging group activities for up to 20 minutes at a time.
Show curiosity by asking “why” questions to learn more.
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Describe life cycles of organisms.
Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Use a wide variety of words to label and describe people, places, things, and actions.
Self-select books and other written materials to engage in prereading behaviors.
Sustain attention to routine tasks until completed
Remain focused on engaging group activities for up to 20 minutes at a time,
Ask and answer questions in order to learn or share information.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the relationship of organisms to their environments.
